verses.text: For, behold, in those days and at that time, when I restore the fortunes of Judah and Jerusalem,
verses.comment: Joel begins a prophecy about the last days and the restoration of God's people, showing a pattern of divine mercy and restoration seen throughout scripture.

verses.text: I will gather all the nations and bring them down to the Valley of Jehoshaphat; there I will enter into judgment with them on behalf of my people and my inheritance, Israel, whom they scattered among the nations; and they divided up my land.
verses.comment: The 'Valley of Jehoshaphat' symbolizes God's final judgment, echoing universal themes of God's justice. The scattering of Israel points to events both historic and prophetic, with restoration and judgment intertwined.

verses.text: They have cast lots for my people; traded boys for prostitutes, and sold girls for wine, that they might drink.
verses.comment: Describes the abuse and dehumanization of Israel. The selling of children for trivial pleasures exposes the depth of societal corruption that draws God’s wrath.

verses.text: Also, what are you to me, Tyre and Sidon, and all the regions of Philistia? Are you repaying me for something? If you repay me, swiftly and quickly I will return your payment upon your own head.
verses.comment: God addresses Tyre, Sidon, and Philistia (Gentile powers), emphasizing His sovereignty over all nations. This counteraction signifies divine justice and the futility of human rebellion.

verses.text: For you have taken my silver and my gold, and carried my precious treasures into your temples.
verses.comment: Describes theft of sacred items, which have spiritual implications regarding the desecration of what belongs to God. The concept of sacred objects reflects deeper realities about worship and reverence.

verses.text: You sold the people of Judah and Jerusalem to the Greeks, in order to remove them far from their own border.
verses.comment: Selling God's people to foreign lands highlights the spiritual exile and longing for true homecoming—a prophecy later fulfilled in Christ’s gathering of scattered peoples.

verses.text: See, I will rouse them from the place you sold them, and I will return your own action on your head.
verses.comment: God promises reversal of injustice. The spiritual principle: God's justice never fails; those who persecute His people face divine recompense.

verses.text: I will sell your sons and your daughters into the hand of the people of Judah, and they shall sell them to the Sabeans, to a nation far away; for the LORD has spoken.
verses.comment: God’s retribution turns the tables. Shows emphasis on the gravity of violating God’s covenant people and reminds of God's fidelity.

verses.text: Proclaim this among the nations: Prepare for war! Stir up the mighty. Let all the fighters draw near; let them come up.
verses.comment: The imagery of martial summons foreshadows eschatological battle. Interpreted both literally and spiritually, it points to spiritual preparation and vigilance before the Day of the Lord.

verses.text: Beat your plowshares into swords, and your pruning hooks into spears; let the weak say, 'I am a warrior.'
verses.comment: A reversal of the peace prophecy (see Isaiah 2:4), signifying the seriousness of the coming judgment. Also points to the spiritual call for every believer to be prepared for battle (Eph. 6:10-18).

verses.text: Hasten and come, all you surrounding nations, and assemble yourselves. Bring down, O LORD, your mighty ones.
verses.comment: The assembling of nations shows both a literal gathering for battle and a spiritual gathering for divine judgment. The 'mighty ones' refers to angelic hosts or sanctified people.

verses.text: Let the nations rise and advance to the Valley of Jehoshaphat; for there I will sit to judge all the surrounding nations.
verses.comment: God Himself is the judge. Valley of Jehoshaphat functions as imagery for the great judgment scene, connecting Old Testament justice traditions to the final judgment depicted in Revelation.

verses.text: Put in the sickle, for the harvest is ripe. Go in and tread, for the winepress is full. The vats overflow, for their wickedness is great.
verses.comment: The harvest and winepress imagery indicate imminent judgment. Revelation references explicitly connect this prophecy to New Testament eschatology, with strong christological implications regarding the final separation.

verses.text: Multitudes, multitudes in the valley of decision! For the day of the LORD is near in the valley of decision.
verses.comment: The 'valley of decision' is a place of final choice and judgment, establishing a theme of urgency that is echoed in Christ’s own warnings about the final day (Matt. 25:31–46).

verses.text: The sun and the moon grow dark, and the stars withdraw their shining.
verses.comment: Cosmic signs mark the arrival of the day of the LORD. These motifs reappear in both Old and New Testaments when describing divine intervention or the coming of the Messiah.

verses.text: The LORD roars from Zion and utters His voice from Jerusalem, and the heavens and the earth tremble. But the LORD is a refuge for His people, a stronghold for the children of Israel.
verses.comment: God is both terrifying in judgment and merciful as a refuge. The image of God roaring from Zion connects to the kingly, priestly role of Christ, who both judges and saves (see John 10:28-30, Heb. 7:24-25).

verses.text: So you shall know that I am the LORD your God, dwelling in Zion, my holy mountain. Jerusalem will be holy, and strangers will pass through it no longer.
verses.comment: God's dwelling in Zion expresses a fulfillment of the temple prophecy, prefiguring the fullness of God’s presence in the New Jerusalem (Rev. 21), and the perpetual holiness and unity of His people.

verses.text: In that day, the mountains shall drip with sweet wine, the hills shall flow with milk, and all the streams of Judah shall flow with water. A fountain shall come forth from the house of the LORD and water the Valley of Acacias.
verses.comment: Abundant blessings symbolize restoration and spiritual nourishment. The fountain from the LORD’s house foreshadows living water flowing from Christ (John 4:14; 7:38), and ongoing sacramental grace.

verses.text: Egypt shall become a desolation and Edom a wilderness, for the violence against the people of Judah, because they have shed innocent blood in their land.
verses.comment: Egypt and Edom represent unrepentant nations opposed to God’s people. God's judgment falls for innocent blood, underscoring the seriousness of justice and mercy in God’s economy.

verses.text: Judah shall be inhabited forever, and Jerusalem from generation to generation.
verses.comment: Eternal inheritance is promised. This prophecy finds spiritual fulfillment in the unity and indestructibility of God’s one people, established by Christ in the new covenant.

verses.text: I will avenge their blood, which I have not yet avenged, for the LORD dwells in Zion.
verses.comment: God’s final justice and perpetual presence—Zion as God’s dwelling—signals the fulfillment of all prophetic promises, culminating in the complete redemption and sanctification of His people.
